Name: DIPOTASSIUM PHOSPHATE
Description: Dipotassium hydrogen phosphate is a potassium salt that is the dipotassium salt of phosphoric acid. It has a role as a buffer. It is a potassium salt and an inorganic phosphate.

mechanism_of_action.References: Hardman, J.G., L.E. Limbird, P.B. Molinoff, R.W. Ruddon, A.G. Goodman (eds.). Goodman and Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics. 9th ed. New York, NY: McGraw-Hill, 1996., p. 1525
mechanism_of_action.Value: Once phosphate gains access to the body fluids and tissues, it exerts little pharmacological effect. If the ion is introduced into the intestine, the absorbed phosphate is rapidly excreted. If large amounts are given by this route, much of it may escape absorption. Because this property leads to a cathartic action, phosphate salts are employed as mild laxatives. Inorganic phosphate poisoning following ingestion of laxatives that contain phosphate salts has been reported in adults and children. Ingestion of large amounts of sodium dihydrogen phosphate lowers urinary pH. If excessive phosphate salts are introduced intravenously or orally, they may prove toxic by reducing the concentration of Ca 2+ in the circulation and from the precipitation of calcium phosphate in soft tissues. /Phosphates/

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: INVESTIGATED BY PLEDGET TECHNIQUE IN 1 ESOPHAGEAL STUDY WITH CATS, PRODUCED EXTENSIVE NECROSIS & ULCERATION. INGESTION MAY PRODUCE OROPHARYNGEAL BURNS, ESOPHAGITIS & GASTRITIS ACCOMPANIED BY ULCERATION, BLEEDING & DIARRHEA.

AFTER ORAL ADMIN OF 0.8 G/KG BODY WT FOR 14 OR 38 WK DOGS VOMITED, WERE CACHECTIC, & HAD ELEVATED CREATININE & BLOOD UREA NITROGEN. RENAL DAMAGE WAS MOST MARKED @ 38 WK, THERE WERE DISSEMINATED ATROPHY (USUALLY OF PROXIMAL TUBLES), FOCAL SCAR TISSUE & NEPHROCALCINOSIS.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Gosselin, R.E., R.P. Smith, H.C. Hodge. Clinical Toxicology of Commercial Products. 5th ed. Baltimore: Williams and Wilkins, 1984., p. II-124
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: ORALLY POISONED ANIMALS DIED FROM RESP FAILURE SOMETIMES FOLLOWING CONVULSIONS & ... GASTROENTERITIS, DEHYDRATION OF ORGANS & EARLY RENAL TUBULAR NECROSIS. /POTASSIUM SALTS/

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Gosselin, R.E., R.P. Smith, H.C. Hodge. Clinical Toxicology of Commercial Products. 5th ed. Baltimore: Williams and Wilkins, 1984., p. II-124
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /ORALLY POISONED ANIMALS/ SURVIVORS HAD ANOREXIA, POLYDIPSIA, POLYURIA, FEVER, CONVULSIVE MOVEMENTS & GI DISTURBANCES DURING FIRST 24 HR, BUT RAPIDLY RECOVERED ... . /POTASSIUM SALTS/

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Venugopal, B. and T.D. Luckey. Metal Toxicity in Mammals, 2. New York: Plenum Press, 1978., p. 16
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: POTASSIUM ... PHOSPHATE CAUSE SEVERE ULCERATION IN THE GI TRACT @ A LEVEL EQUIVALENT TO 1000 MG K+ ION WHEN GIVEN TO MONKEYS IN FORM OF A PILL. /POTASSIUM PHOSPHATE/

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Furia, T.E. (ed.). CRC Handbook of Food Additives. 2nd ed. Cleveland: The Chemical Rubber Co., 1972., p. 635
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: PHOSPHATES ... ARE TOXIC TO ANY ORGANISM INGESTING EXCESS QUANTITIES OF THE SALTS. EXCESS INGESTION OF ANY INORG SALT MAY UPSET MINERAL BALANCE IN BODY, ADVERSELY AFFECT OSMOTIC PRESSURE OF BODY FLUIDS & PREVENT ABSORPTION OR UTILIZATION OF NECESSARY MINERAL NUTRIENTS. /PHOSPHATES/

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Furia, T.E. (ed.). CRC Handbook of Food Additives. 2nd ed. Cleveland: The Chemical Rubber Co., 1972., p. 758
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: THE EFFECTIVE /DIETARY/ LEVELS OF PHOSPHATES ARE USUALLY 0.5% OR LESS. WHEN THIS LEVEL ... WAS CONSUMED IN DIETS OF MANY ANIMALS, IT WAS SHOWN TO BE NONTOXIC. /PHOSPHATES/

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Furia, T.E. (ed.). CRC Handbook of Food Additives. 2nd ed. Cleveland: The Chemical Rubber Co., 1972., p. 642
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: ... ANIMAL-FEEDING STUDIES ... INDICATE THAT LEVELS OF 0.5% ... PHOSPHATE COULD BE TOLERATED IN DIET WITHOUT ADVERSE PHYSIOLOGICAL EFFECTS. HIGHER LEVELS COULD ... BE TOLERATED IF PROPER ... BALANCE OF ... IONS ... CALCIUM, MAGNESIUM & POTASSIUM, IS MAINTAINED. /PHOSPHATES/
